questions.text: A 47-year-old with a history of smoking for the last 10 years has presented with hoarseness of voice for the last 3 weeks. The fibreoptic laryngoscopy image has been shown in the given image. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given fibreoptic laryngoscopy image suggests glottic malignancy with features of

  • Irregular, exophytic growth
  • Whitish patches over the true vocal cord
  • Located within the glottic region (between the vocal folds)

Glottic Cancer (Laryngeal Cancer Originating in the Glottis)

Common site:

  • Anterior and middle third of the free edge and upper surface of the true vocal cord.

Local spread pattern:

  • Anteriorly → Anterior commissure → Opposite vocal cord
  • Posteriorly → Vocal process and arytenoid
  • Upward → Ventricle and false cord
  • Downward → Subglottic region

Vocal cord mobility:

  • Normal in early stages
  • Fixation indicates spread to the thyroarytenoid muscle → Poor prognosis

Lymphatic spread:

  • Rare in early cordal lesions due to sparse lymphatics
  • Nodal metastasis usually occurs only after extension beyond the membranous cord

Clinical feature:

  • Hoarseness of voice is often the first and earliest symptom, due to impaired vocal cord vibration
  • Early symptom leads to early detection

Explanation for other options:

Adult papilloma of the larynx (Option A): Presents as multiple warty growths

  • Not as irregular and infiltrative as seen in malignancy
  • Rare in adults; more common in recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (juvenile type)

Reinke's oedema (Option B): Presents with bilateral, smooth, translucent swelling of the vocal cords

  • More common in female smokers
  • No exophytic or irregular lesion

Supraglottic malignancy (Option D): The lesion here is not in the supraglottic area

  • Supraglottic tumours present with dysphagia, referred otalgia, or airway compromise more commonly

questions.text: Which of the following is the best description of Type III cordectomy
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The classification by the European Laryngological Society (ELS) defines transmuscular cordectomy as Type III, which is performed by cutting through the vocalis muscle.

  • The resection encompasses the epithelium, lamina propria, and part of the vocalis muscle.
  • The resection may extend from the vocal process to the anterior commissure, preserving some surrounding tissue, unlike total cordectomy.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for the T3 stage of Laryngeal cancer
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The treatment of choice for the T3 stage of Laryngeal cancer with fixed cords is total laryngectomy followed by radiotherapy.

  • The entire larynx, including the hyoid bone, pre-epiglottic space, strap muscles, and one or more rings of trachea, is removed.
  • The pharyngeal wall is repaired, and the lower tracheal stump is sutured to the skin for breathing.
  • Laryngectomy may be combined with block dissection for nodal metastasis.

Indications for total laryngectomy

  • T3 lesions (i.e., with cord fixed)
  • All T4 lesions
  • Invasion of the thyroid or cricoid cartilage
  • Bilateral arytenoid cartilage involvement
  • Lesions of the posterior commissure
  • Failure after radiotherapy or conservative surgery
  • Transglottic cancers, e., tumours involving the supraglottis and glottis across the ventricle, causing fixation of the vocal cord.

It is contraindicated in patients with distant metastasis.

Explanation for other options:

Radiotherapy (Option A):

  • Curative radiotherapy is reserved for early lesions that neither impair cord mobility nor invade cartilage or cervical nodes.
  • Cancer of the vocal cord without impairment of its mobility gives a 90% cure rate after irradiation and has the advantage of preservation of voice.
  • Superficial exophytic lesions, especially of the tip of the epiglottis and aryepiglottic folds, give a 70-90% cure rate.
  • Radiotherapy does not give good results in lesions with fixed cords, subglottic extension, cartilage invasion, and nodal metastases. These lesions require surgery.

Chemoradiation (Option C): Organ preservation with concurrent chemoradiation is often attempted in T3 cases with mobile cords or a partially functioning larynx. It's an alternative, not the first choice, if cords are fixed.

Hemilaryngectomy (Option D): This is only suitable for selected T1 or T2 glottic cancers. T3 cancers typically have deep invasion or cord fixation, making partial procedures ineffective.

questions.text: Which drug has a role as a local application agent in Juvenile Onset Respiratory Papillomatosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

 Intralesional cidofovir is a particularly important drug in Juvenile Onset Respiratory Papillomatosis (JORP).

  • It is injected directly into the lesions to reduce recurrence and limit the need for repeated surgeries.
  • It inhibits viral DNA polymerase, particularly effective against HPV types 6 and 11.

Juvenile-Onset Recurrent Respiratory Papillomatosis (JORRP):

  • Affects children aged 3-6 years, caused by HPV types 6 & 11, often transmitted during vaginal delivery from mothers with genital warts (C-section preferred).
  • Presents with multiple warty lesions on the vocal cords, possibly extending to the trachea/bronchi. Premalignant in nature
  • Symptoms include chronic hoarseness, stridor, and respiratory distress.
  • Treated by CO2 laser excision via microlaryngoscopy (MLS)
  • Agents used to decrease the recurrence rate after surgery include intralesional cidofovir, interferon alpha 2a or 2b (Zuma), indole-3-carbinol (from broccoli), and six retinoic acids.

Explanation for other options:

Valacyclovir (Option B): Used for the Herpes virus, not effective against HPV.

Indinavir (Option C): An HIV protease inhibitor, no role in HPV-related diseases.

Abacavir (Option D): A nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) for HIV, not useful in JORRP.

questions.text: All are causes for Right Recurrent Laryngeal nerve palsy except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Aortic aneurysm is a cause for left recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis; all others are causes for right recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis.

questions.text: An 80-year-old male, Ramu, presents with progressive dyspnea, stridor, dysphagia, and weight loss. He also reports referred otalgia. Indirect laryngoscopy reveals a growth involving the subglottic region with fixed vocal cords. Imaging shows invasion into the prevertebral space. Biopsy from direct laryngoscopy confirms squamous cell carcinoma. Clinically, the patient is suffering from:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Invasion of prevertebral space, carotid artery, or mediastinal structures with a growth involving the subglottic region with fixed vocal cords indicates stage T4b Subglottic Carcinoma.

TNM Classification of Cancer Larynx (American Joint Committee on Cancer, 2002)

questions.text: Komal, a 4-year-old child, has been brought to the ENT OPD with the complaint of persistent and progressively increasing hoarseness of voice for the last 3 months. There is no history of vocal abuse. Her fibreoptic laryngeal endoscopy picture is given in the image. What would be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows papillomatosis growths in the larynx. So, juvenile papilloma of the larynx is the most likely diagnosis.

Juvenile Laryngeal Papillomatosis

Aetiology & Pathogenesis:

  • Most common benign laryngeal neoplasm in children.
  • Caused by Human Papillomavirus (HPV) types 6 and 11.
  • Transmitted from mother to child during vaginal delivery (perinatal transmission).

Sites Affected:

  • Primarily involves the supraglottic and glottic regions.
  • May extend to subglottis, trachea, bronchi, and stoma (especially post-tracheostomy due to seeding).

Clinical Features:

  • The onset usually occurs between 3-5 years of age.
  • Presents with:
    • Hoarseness or aphonia
    • Respiratory distress or stridor

Diagnosis:


  • Initial: Flexible fiberoptic laryngoscopy.
  • Confirmatory: Direct laryngoscopy with biopsy.

Treatment:

  • Mainstay: Microlaryngoscopy with CO2 laser excision, otherwise cup forceps or microdebrider.
  • The aim is to preserve the airway, voice and reduce recurrence.
  • Agents used to decrease the recurrence rate after surgery include intralesional cidofovir, interferon alpha 2a or 2b (Zuma), indole-3-carbinol (from broccoli), and six retinoic acids, with intralesional cidofovir being particularly important.

Explanation for other options:

Vocal Nodules (Option A): Typically bilateral, symmetric, small nodules located at the junction of the anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd of the vocal cords. Seen in older children and adults, often due to vocal abuse (screaming, singing). Less likely in a 4-year-old with no vocal abuse history and multiple exophytic lesions.

Reinke's Oedema (Option C): Caused by chronic irritation (smoking, hypothyroidism, voice overuse). Typically affects middle-aged adults, especially women, with boggy, translucent swelling of both vocal cords. Not seen in children.

Vocal Polyp (Option D): Typically unilateral, pedunculated or sessile lesions. Seen in adults, due to vocal trauma or inflammation. More localised than papillomas and rare in children.

questions.text: A case of carcinoma larynx presents with the involvement of the Left vocal cord, left aryepiglottic fold, left ventricular band, and invading into the paraglottic space. Which of the following statements is true for the management of this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is stage T3 laryngeal carcinoma as the paraglottic space is involved. The treatment of choice for T3 and T4 cancer larynx is total laryngectomy followed by radiotherapy.

  • However, certain cancer study groups recommend the use of concurrent chemoradiation with Cisplatin for T3 cancer larynx as an alternative to total laryngectomy.
  • Though the 5-year survival rate with concurrent chemoradiation is lower than compared of surgical management.

questions.text: A 63-year-old patient has undergone total laryngectomy for advanced laryngeal cancer. During surgery, the surgeon has placed the device shown in the image by creating a fistula between adjoining structures. What is the name of this device?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The name of the given device is the Blom Singer Prosthesis

  • The Blom singer prosthesis is a tracheoesophageal puncture device.
  • It is a one-way valve surgically placed between the trachea and the oesophagus.
  • It is used for vocal rehabilitation after laryngectomy.
  • It sends air from the trachea to the oesophagus, which is used to produce the voice.
  • But it does not let the food particles go from the oesophagus to the trachea, so aspiration is not significant.

Explanation for other options:

Montgomery's Tracheal T tube (Option A): Used to stent the trachea in cases of stenosis or collapse, not for voice rehabilitation.

Fuller's tube (Option C): Rarely used; historically described for airway management, not for vocal rehabilitation.

Artificial larynx (Option D): A handheld external electronic device (e.g., electrolarynx), not an internal prosthesis placed during surgery.

questions.text:
A patient of T3N0M0 carcinoma larynx has undergone total laryngectomy. He has a permanent tracheostomy following this surgery. He is using the device given in the picture for vocal rehabilitation.

What is the name of this device?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The electrolarynx is the instrument shown in the picture

  • Battery-operated, handheld portable device.
  • Its vibrating disc is held against the soft tissues of the neck, and a low-pitched sound is produced in the hypopharynx, which is further modulated into speech by the tongue, lips, teeth, and palate.
  • Used in those who fail to learn oesophageal speech

Explanation for other options:

Blom Singer prosthesis (Option B): This is an internal voice prosthesis inserted between the trachea and oesophagus (tracheoesophageal puncture). It requires surgical placement and allows air to vibrate the oesophageal mucosa. Not an external device like the one shown.

Oesophageal speech device (Option C): This is not an actual device. It refers to a technique where the patient learns to "swallow" air and release it to produce sound. Requires training and effort. No hardware involved.

Panje Device (Option D): An older type of voice prosthesis, now rarely used. It is an internal prosthesis, not the external vibrating device shown in the image.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male chronic smoker complains of hoarseness for the past 4 months. Microlaryngoscopy biopsy shows it to be keratosis of the larynx. All the suggested treatment modalities for this condition, except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Leukoplakia or keratosis of the larynx is a premalignant epithelial hyperplasia involving the upper surface of the vocal cords. Treatment includes

  • Stripping of vocal cords followed by histology of tissue for any malignant change.
  • A laser vaporiser can also be used.
  • Chronic laryngeal irritants should be eliminated.


  • Partial laryngectomy is done for the T2 stage of carcinoma larynx.

Explanation for other options:

Laser cordectomy (Option A): Laser excision is an accepted and commonly used modality for treating keratosis, especially when there's concern for dysplasia or early malignancy. Used to remove the keratotic lesion precisely with minimal damage

Elimination of chronic laryngeal irritants (Option B): Keratosis is often caused or worsened by chronic irritation, like smoking, acid reflux, and voice abuse. An essential part of conservative treatment is to reduce recurrence or progression to cancer.

Stripping of the vocal cord (Option C): This is a classic technique where the epithelium is peeled from the vocal cord. Often performed for diffuse keratosis, especially when biopsy and treatment are done together.

questions.text: Which of the following is a tracheoesophageal puncture device used for post-laryngectomy vocal rehabilitation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Provox prosthesis is a tracheoesophageal puncture (TEP) voice prosthesis used for vocal rehabilitation after total laryngectomy. It allows pulmonary air to pass from the trachea into the oesophagus, enabling speech by vibrating the pharyngoesophageal segment.

Tracheoesophageal Puncture Device

  • These include the Blom singer prosthesis, the Panje and the Provox prosthesis.
  • It is a one-way valve surgically placed between the trachea and the oesophagus.
  • Used for vocal rehabilitation after laryngectomy. It sends air from the trachea to the oesophagus, which is used to produce the voice. But it does not let the food particles go from the oesophagus to the trachea, so aspiration is not significant.

Explanation for other options:

Chevalier Jackson tube: (Option A) A rigid bronchoscope or oesophagoscope used for foreign body removal.

Montgomery's Tracheal T tube: (Option C) Used to stent the trachea in cases of stenosis or collapse, not for voice rehabilitation.

McNaught Keel: (Option D) A keel used to prevent anterior glottic web formation after laryngeal surgery.

choices.text: It is a hyperkeratotic lesion present in the interarytenoid region

questions.text: A 45-year-old male, a chronic smoker, presents with hoarseness of voice for several months. On laryngoscopic examination, he is suspected to have pachydermoperiostitis. Which of the following statements about pachydermia laryngis is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pachydermia laryngis is not a premalignant condition

Pachydermia laryngis:

  • It is a hyperkeratotic lesion with heaping of epithelium in the interarytenoid region (Option A ruled out)
  • Aetiology - laryngopharyngeal reflux (LPR), voice abuse (Option D ruled out)
  • Clinical feature: hoarseness
  • "cobblestone-like appearance"- on examination
  • A biopsy is required to differentiate from carcinoma and tuberculosis. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with persistent hoarseness of voice for 2 months. On laryngoscopic examination, a small glottic lesion confined to one vocal cord is noted. Biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma. There is no nodal involvement or distant metastasis (T1N0M0). What is the ideal treatment option for this stage of glottic cancer?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Laser cordectomy is the ideal treatment for early-stage glottic tumours, with recent advances,

  • T1N0M0 glottic malignancy - Tumour limited to vocal cord(s) with normal mobility.
  • Carcinoma of the mobile membranous vocal cord is traditionally treated with radiotherapy.
  • Now, such lesions are precisely excised with a CO2 laser under a microscope with the same good results.
  • Laser excision has the advantages of lower cost, lower duration of treatment, and lower morbidity.

Explanation for other options:

Radiotherapy (Option A): Carcinoma of the mobile membranous vocal cord is traditionally treated with radiotherapy. Excellent voice preservation, high cure rates, and non-invasive. But, due to advanced surgical techniques, they are replaced.

Total Laryngectomy (Option C): Not suitable for early-stage glottic cancer (T1). Reserved for T3/T4 lesions, or recurrent/resistant disease. Results in permanent tracheostomy and voice loss.

Decortication of Vocal Cord (Option D): Non-standard, older term; refers to superficial stripping. Not a definitive oncologic treatment for carcinoma. Not recommended for invasive malignancy.

choices.text: Vertical partial laryngectomy is done for T2 N0 glottic malignancy
Horizontal partial laryngectomy should be done only if both vocal cords are normal
Good pulmonary reserve is needed for partial laryngectomy
Patient has a permanent tracheostomy after partial laryngectomy

questions.text: All are true about partial laryngectomy except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient does not need to have a permanent tracheostomy after total laryngectomy.

  • Most patients are decannulated after recovery. Permanent tracheostomy is more common after total laryngectomy.
  • Partial laryngectomy is done for T2N0 carcinoma larynx.

Explanation for other options:

Vertical partial laryngectomy is commonly done for T1-T2 glottic cancers, especially when the lesion is confined to one vocal cord or the anterior commissure. (Option A ruled out)

Horizontal partial laryngectomy (e.g., supraglottic laryngectomy) requires preserved vocal cord mobility; both cords should ideally be functional to maintain airway and phonation post-op. (Option B ruled out)

Patients need good pulmonary reserve, as partial laryngectomy can temporarily compromise airway clearance and coughing. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: General contraindications for partial laryngectomies include all except :
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Partial laryngectomy is done for T2 carcinoma larynx.

  • Supraglottic extension is not a contraindication for partial laryngectomy.
  • Fixed cords imply stage T3 (Option A ruled out)
  • Cartilage invasion, significant oropharyngeal extension implies stage T4a (Option B and D ruled out)
>

questions.text: Vertical partial laryngectomy is done for
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vertical partial laryngectomy is done for T2N0M0 glottic cancer. Vertical Partial Laryngectomy (VPL) is a voice-preserving surgery done primarily for glottic cancers where the lesion is confined to one vocal cord and possibly extends to the anterior commissure or vocal process of the arytenoid without fixation.

Indications for Vertical Partial Laryngectomy:

  • T1 or T2 glottic cancer (especially T2 with preserved cord mobility or limited impaired mobility)
  • No nodal involvement (N0)
  • Lesion not involving both cords extensively or the posterior commissure.

Explanation for other options:

  • Horizontal partial laryngectomy is done for T2N0M0 supraglottic cancer. The prerequisite is that the growth should be limited to supraglottis, and both vocal cords are free and mobile. The lung functions should also be good (Option B ruled out)
  • T1N0M0 Glottic cancer and T1N0M0 Supraglottic Cancer are usually treated with radiotherapy or laser cordectomy, not necessarily requiring VPL. (Option A and D ruled out)

questions.text: Horizontal partial laryngectomy is done for
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Horizontal partial laryngectomy is done for T2N0M0 supraglottic cancer.

  • The prerequisite is that the growth should be limited to supraglottis, and both vocal cords are free and mobile.
  • The lung functions should also be good, as partial laryngectomy can temporarily compromise airway clearance and coughing.
  • Vertical partial laryngectomy is done for T2N0M0 glottic cancer. The growth should be limited to one side, and the other side should be free.

Explanation for other options:

T1N0M0 Glottic Cancer (Option A):

  • Typically managed with radiotherapy or laser cordectomy.
  • Horizontal partial laryngectomy is not required for small, well-localised glottic tumours.

T2N0M0 Glottic Cancer (Option C):

  • Managed by radiotherapy, laser excision, or vertical partial laryngectomy (cordectomy/hemilaryngectomy) depending on extent and vocal cord mobility.
  • Horizontal partial laryngectomy is not suitable as the lesion is glottic, not supraglottic.

T1N0M0 Supraglottic Cancer (Option D):

  • Often managed with radiotherapy or transoral laser microsurgery.
  • Horizontal partial laryngectomy can be considered, but is usually reserved for more extensive disease (i.e., T2).
